item.title: Pokémon Scarlet/Violet DLC Cost as Much to Make as Legends: Arceus, Leaks Reveal
item.content:encoded:
New leaks have revealed that Pokémon Scarlet/Violet’s cost went way over budget, matching the likes of Pokémon Legends: Arceus’ entire development.

A massive number of leaks have surfaced online about the Pokémon franchise since yesterday, revealing details about past, present, and future games. We have already been informed about the Gen 10 title, Wind and Wave, and a roadmap for future Pokémon games. Now, new details about Scarlet and Violet’s DLC have also surfaced online.

Pokémon Scarlet and Violet’s Expansion Brought In 6.15 Million Downloads

As revealed by the reliable CentroLeaks on X (formerly Twitter), the cost for Pokémon Scarlet and Violet’s DLC development surpassed their estimated budgets enormously, reaching “as much as the entire Legends: Arceus development”. After that, the development team decided that DLCs would be kept “at an appropriate scale commensurate with the revenue, and focus on achieving low costs”. In the first 10 months, the DLC sold 6.15 million downloads, which is 25% of the players that own the game.

DLCs Became a Mandate After Pokémon Scarlet and Violet’s Expansion

A previous post from Centro also talks about troubles during the development of the Pokémon Scarlet and Violet DLC, which led to a decision that many fans will be happy about. It seems that the DLC was not planned from the beginning, which led to a bug that affected development. After this issue, “Game Freak mandated that all future games will be programmed assuming DLC will be made.” Which means all future Pokémon games will be made with an expansion in mind.

Pokémon has revealed that 6:00 UTC is the official start time for Season 1 Ranked.

Here’s a quick time breakdown of what this looks like for different regions if you’re having trouble converting UTC to your time zone.

item.title: Call of Duty Exists Because “EA Were D***s”, Says Vince Zampella
item.content:encoded:
The current lead for the Battlefield franchise has stated that the only reason Call of Duty exists is because EA had a fallout with him.

The Battlefield franchise is back to its victory days with the release of BF6, finally giving the likes of Call of Duty some serious competition. Their last title, Battlefield 2042, didn’t perform well with fans, but the developers have pulled off a complete turnaround, with BF6 reaching almost 750k concurrent players on launch day.

Vince Zampella Reveals Call of Duty is Only Here Because ‘EA Were D***s’

During a new interview with GQ (via GamesRadar+), Vince Zampella spoke about Call of Duty’s existence. The executive vice president at Electronic Arts stated, “The only reason that Call of Duty exists is because EA were dicks”. For those unaware about Zampella’s past, he left EA after a dispute, only to make Infinity Ward in 2002, which led to the creation of the Call of Duty franchise. He later returned to EA to oversee games such as Titanfall, Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order, and Apex Legends.

Vince Zampella is a true veteran of the shooter genre, delivering players with some of the biggest hits in this space. He started with Medal of Honor: Allied Assault, where we worked closely with Steven Spielberg. After the dispute, Activision tasked him with creating a franchise that would kill Medal of Honor, and that was Call of Duty. However, after that, he returned to EA and is now overseeing the latest big thing in the FPS space, Battlefield.

In other news, Battlefield 6’s campaign offers players an uninstall button after completion. Additionally, Black Ops 7 beta matches were nearly 99% cheater-free. item.title: Sucker Punch Could Make A New Sly Cooper Or inFamous Game After Ghost of Yotei
item.content:encoded:
PlayStation has benefited from the mammoth exclusive launch of Ghost of Yotei—the follow-up to Ghost of Tsushima. Now, Sucker Punch is already looking ahead to a potential Sly Cooper or Infamous game as the next project.

Aside from 1999’s forgotten Rocket: Robot On Wheels, the American-based team known as Sucker Punch Studios got its career firmly on track with 2001’s Sly Cooper and the Thievius Raccoonus. This led to a further two Sly games (the fourth being handled by Sanzaru Games), before moving onto the inFamous franchise. 2009 to 2014 saw five separate inFamous experiences, and then it was time for Ghost of Tsushima.

Once Ghost of Yotei‘s Legends multiplayer update has been added, Sucker Punch is weighing up what to do next.

“Going Back To Sly” A Serious Possibility For Sucker Punch Studios

In an interview with VideoGamer, Sucker Punch studio head and co-founder Brian Fleming said: “Whatever we do next, whether it’s continuing Ghost or going back to Sly, the decision is really more limited by, again, our cherishing of focus and time to iterate, which means that we really can only do one thing at a time”.

Fleming indicates that despite the studio’s size, it can’t do more than one project at a time.

This follows an interview with GameInformer, where Ghost of Yotei co-creative director Nate Fox said he “Would love Sucker Punch to work on more InFamous.” Again, whatever the company decides, it will likely be the only piece of media the studio develops for a few years.

Sucker Punch Productions has steadily become one of the most prolific and premium game studios in the world. You never hear bad words or controversy about it, and the company goes about its business creating one incredible game after another. With the main bulk of Ghost of Yotei’s development complete—aside from post-launch content—the future could be interesting.

item.title: Assassin’s Creed Shadows Switch 2 Release Date Leaks Online
item.content:encoded:
According to a reliable source, Assassin’s Creed Shadows is set to arrive for the Nintendo Switch 2 this year, on December 5, 2025.

Rumours about Assassin’s Creed Shadows coming to Switch 2 have been popping up for a long time now. We first saw a PEGI rating for the Switch 2 port surface online, and then, recently, a listing at a French storefront was revealed with a placeholder image and product description. Now, we have the release date as well for AC Shadows on Switch 2.

Assassin’s Creed Shadows Arrives for Switch 2 This December

A report from Dealabs reveals that, through their investigations, they have confirmed that Assassin’s Creed Shadows will arrive for the Nintendo Switch 2 on December 5, 2025. The game will also receive a physical version, but it will be on a game key card, meaning players will have to download it to their console.

The pre-order date for AC Shadows on Switch 2 hasn’t been confirmed, but according to their data, it should begin by November 7. Lastly, the price for the Switch 2 port has been revealed, and it seems the game can be purchased for around €50, with some retailers offering promotional offers.

For those unaware, Assassin’s Creed Shadows is set in feudal Japan, where players step into the shoes of 2 heroes, Naoe and Yasuke, and experience the story from 2 perspectives. Naoe is a quick-witted shinobi who excels in stealth and shadows. At the same time, Yasuke is a formidable samurai with expertise in strength and steel.

Assassin’s Creed Shadows has also already received its Claws of Awaji DLC, which adds 10 hours of content to the game, along with a new weapon, skills, and abilities. Naoe and Yasuke embark on a new adventure to secure an object for Japan’s future.

item.title: Pokémon TCG Pocket Year One Anniversary Update Includes Huge Wonder Pick Buff
item.content:encoded:
It’s hard to believe it’s been a year since Pokémon TCG Pocket launched. The mobile-only card-collecting experience has been a great imitation of real-life buying, collecting, and trading, and Pocket is undergoing significant changes as part of its first anniversary.

Pokémon TCG Pocket is a much cheaper alternative to collecting physical Pokémon cards. It has proven to be another money-making phenomenon, with regular updates adding new sets and features. While the community is still divided over Deluxe Pack ex, more updates are being prepared in the background.

Pokémon TCG Pocket Updating Trading & Wonder Picks

Pokémon TCG Pocket’s first anniversary is set to bring three major changes and improvements: A new Share feature, an upgrade to Trading, and improved Wonder Picks.

Firstly, the new Share feature allows you to gift one of your friends a card between one and four-Diamond rarity once a day. A quick one-off gift that should allow you to fill any collection gaps much faster.

The second change is the range of tradeable cards you can choose from. Recent booster packs will now be eligible for trading, and you’re no longer restricted to the old-school rarity limits.

The game will allow you to trade the following rarities:

  • One-Diamond
  • Two-Diamond
  • Three-Diamond
  • Four-Diamond
  • One-Star
  • Two-Star
  • One-Shiny
  • Two-Shiny

Finally, the Wonder Pick mechanic is getting a decent overhaul. The only meaningful change since the game’s launch has been the Sneak Peek bonus that appears every now and again—and it doesn’t even activate that often.

According to the official Pokémon Pocket channel: “Cards from the latest expansion you have not obtained will appear more often,” and “The number of cards you currently own will be displayed on each card in Wonder Pick.”

The anniversary announcement doesn’t say when any of these features are dropping. We’ll have to wait and see on this.

It’s clear the team is listening to the fanbase. Do you think these changes address key areas of the game? Is there anything else that needs to be tweaked or added? Let us know through the Insider Gaming Forum.
